comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Or maybe a 4-4-0. According to wikipedia the last 4-4-0T was withdrawn in 1939.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Yep. Apparently it's a GNIR class PP 4-4-0.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Three post ment! Also OSI link: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,714777,735387,7,9

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Wikipedia says: PP 4-4-0 12, 25, 42–46, 50, 70–71, 74–77, 106–107, 129 17 Beyer, Peacock & Co. (15) Dundalk Works (2) 1896–1911

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] To clarify: 1896–1911 is when the class was built, not their lifetime. They were refurbished with superheaters and continued in service until 1963.

comment.author: 16261194@N00
comment._content: As nostalgic as people are for old Steam locos, my mum still dislikes them. In her day, the sound of the steam whistle would mean sprinting out to bring in the washing before it was covered in soot from the smoke, and if you missed it, having to wash it all again (back when there was only cloth nappies and big families)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
If the Health and Safety Authority bods saw this they'd have a hissy fit (technical term Carol?)  Neither man has a harness, neither is wearing safety glasses, no hard hats, no protective gloves, leaning in over a water filled pit without a life-preserver, standing on the front panel of an engine without a restraint, and the list goes on and on and on...
It's still a lovely shot and is a great reminder of other times.  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rothar] Alan, I remember travelling in such trains and seeing people clear their lines, especially of whites, and also if you put your head out the window you were liable to get "smuts" into your eye which was very uncomfortable!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rothar] It's nice to see the odd one but you wouldn't want them back. They were dirty and inefficient, especially the irish engines. I don't think any of them were even built with roller bearings, let alone streamlining or triple explansion or what have you.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: A lovely photo, though must have been quite a dirty damp place to work. The locomotive is one of the Great Southern & Western's H.A.Ivatt designed 2-4-2 tank engines. No.42, built 1893, was designated as Class F6, and lasted 70 years(!) in service, finally withdrawn in 1963. In fact when captured by O'Dea in 1961 it was the last of its type left. The station at Broadstone was closed back in 1937, but it was the steam locomotive shed that closed in 1961.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Great photograph......No 42 at Inchicore in 1932.... and again in Broadstone 1960.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rothar] Except for genuine enthusiasts, maybe it is more the idea of them than the reality that people hanker for? Can well understand your mother's rage! Personally, I love to hear the whistle...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Yes indeed, hissy fit is one of our glossary of technical terms, though used less often than my favourite - caniption!

comment._content: This is excellent Carol.

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Very good photo! Is there a large rail yard in Ireland? A place where one can see the various engines and rolling stock and other rail equipment?

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Wow, nice. Have to keep them clean and shiny.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48236157@N02] The best website is the Railway Preservation Society of Ireland. www.steamtrainsireland.com/ Australia still has a large network of Irish Gauge railways (5 foot 3 inches) in Victoria and South Australia. I wonder if they have any spare steam locos? Victorian Railways "Heavy Harry" would break every railway bridge in Ireland. www.flickr.com/photos/48106230@N06/5497441683/

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Thank you blackpoolbaech! I am a big fan of trains. All types. And from all countries!

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Hi Carol, yes Broadstone station is the site in general! After 1937 the passenger part of the station became the bus depot/offices, but the locomotive servicing side remained until 1961.

Residents' memories not so sound after all!
